skill.name: competitive-landscape
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "analyze competitors", "assess competitive landscape", "identify differentiation", "evaluate market positioning", "apply Porter's Five Forces", or requests competitive strategy analysis.
skill.summary: Strategic frameworks for analyzing competition, identifying differentiation opportunities, and developing market positioning strategies.
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Static analysis flagged markdown documentation as security issues. All findings are false positives: backticks are markdown code block delimiters, not shell execution; YAML frontmatter and table content were misinterpreted. This is pure documentation with no code execution, network access, or system interaction.

medium_findings.title: Ruby/Shell Backtick Execution (False Positive)
medium_findings.description: Static scanner detected backticks as command execution. These are markdown code block fences, not Ruby/shell backticks.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: All 13 locations contain markdown triple-backtick code block delimiters (```), not Ruby/shell backtick execution. This is standard markdown syntax for code examples.

low_findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm (False Positive)
low_findings.description: Static scanner flagged YAML frontmatter and table content as cryptographic code.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Line 3 is YAML frontmatter delimiters (---), line 222 is table content. Neither involves cryptographic algorithms.

low_findings.title: System Reconnaissance (False Positive)
low_findings.description: Static scanner flagged table content as system reconnaissance.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Line 358 contains a pricing comparison table. No system commands, network requests, or reconnaissance activity present.

content.value_statement: Analyzing competitors and market positioning is time-consuming and requires structured frameworks. This skill provides Porter's Five Forces, Blue Ocean Strategy, and positioning maps to systematically assess competition and identify differentiation opportunities.
actual_capabilities: Apply Porter's Five Forces to assess industry attractiveness and competitive intensity
Create positioning maps to visualize competitive space and identify market gaps
Use Blue Ocean Strategy framework to identify uncontested market opportunities
Profile competitors with structured analysis of strengths, weaknesses, and strategy
Develop sustainable competitive advantages using network effects, switching costs, and economies of scale
Design go-to-market strategies including direct competition, niche focus, and disruptive innovation
limitations: Does not provide real-time competitive intelligence or market data
Cannot access competitor websites, news, or proprietary information
Does not perform financial analysis or valuation of competitors
Cannot replace human judgment in interpreting strategic options

use_cases.title: Startup founders developing market entry strategy
use_cases.description: Use Porter's Five Forces to assess industry attractiveness and Blue Ocean Strategy to find uncontested market space before launching a new venture.

use_cases.title: Product managers conducting competitive analysis
use_cases.description: Profile key competitors systematically using the competitor profile template to understand their positioning, strengths, weaknesses, and likely next moves.

use_cases.title: Business analysts evaluating market positioning
use_cases.description: Create positioning maps and differentiation strategies to identify where your product fits relative to competitors and how to communicate unique value.

prompt_templates.title: Quick competitive overview
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the competitive-landscape skill to analyze the [industry: e.g., SaaS project management] market. Identify the top 5 competitors and apply Porter's Five Forces to assess industry attractiveness.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need a rapid assessment of a market

prompt_templates.title: Porter's Five Forces analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply Porter's Five Forces framework to analyze [specific industry or market]. For each of the five forces (new entrants, supplier power, buyer power, substitutes, rivalry), assess intensity and identify key factors. Provide an overall industry attractiveness rating.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need structured industry analysis

prompt_templates.title: Positioning map creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a positioning map for the [specific market] industry. Choose two relevant dimensions (like price vs. features, or simplicity vs. capability). Plot major competitors and identify any white space opportunities for differentiation.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to visualize competitive positioning

prompt_templates.title: Differentiation strategy development
prompt_templates.prompt: Develop a differentiation strategy for a [type of product/company] entering the [specific market]. Use the Four Actions Framework (Eliminate, Reduce, Raise, Create) from Blue Ocean Strategy. Identify what factors to change to create uncontested market space.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need to define unique market positioning

output_examples.input: Analyze the email marketing SaaS competitive landscape using Porter's Five Forces
output: - Low capital requirements to build basic tools
- However, network effects and data advantages protect incumbents
- Cloud infrastructure is commoditized (AWS, GCP, Azure)
- Many SMB buyers with moderate switching costs
- Enterprise buyers have more negotiation power
- SMS, push notifications, social media are alternatives
- However, email remains highest ROI channel
- Many players: Klaviyo, Mailchimp, HubSpot, ActiveCampaign
**Overall Assessment:** Medium industry attractiveness with high rivalry. Differentiation through deliverability, automation depth, or vertical specialization is critical.

output_examples.input: Create a positioning map for project management software
output: Dimensions: Price (Low to High) vs. Complexity (Simple to Enterprise)
- Top-right quadrant (high price, high complexity) is crowded with enterprise players
- Bottom-left quadrant (low price, simple) has room for disruption
- White space opportunity: Simple tools with premium pricing for mid-market
- Asana and Notion are competing on the simplicity axis while moving upmarket

best_practices: Start with Porter's Five Forces to understand industry dynamics before diving into competitor specifics
Use multiple frameworks together: Five Forces for industry, positioning maps for competition, and Blue Ocean for differentiation
Validate white space opportunities with real customer needs before committing to a positioning strategy
anti_patterns: Avoid head-to-head competition without clear differentiation on dimensions customers value
Do not ignore substitutes and indirect competition when assessing market position
Do not skip competitor profiling - understanding rival strategies helps anticipate their moves

faq.question: What is Porter's Five Forces and when should I use it?
faq.answer: Porter's Five Forces is a framework for analyzing industry attractiveness and competitive intensity. Use it when entering a new market, evaluating industry dynamics, or assessing strategic positioning. The five forces are: threat of new entrants, supplier power, buyer power, threat of substitutes, and competitive rivalry.

faq.question: How is Blue Ocean Strategy different from competitive analysis?
faq.answer: Blue Ocean Strategy focuses on creating uncontested market space rather than competing head-on. While competitive analysis studies existing competitors, Blue Ocean asks what factors can be eliminated, reduced, raised, and created to make competition irrelevant.

faq.question: What makes a good positioning map?
faq.answer: A good positioning map uses two dimensions that matter to customers, plots all relevant competitors, and clearly identifies white space. The dimensions should be independent (not correlated) and represent genuine customer choice criteria.

faq.question: How do I identify sustainable competitive advantages?
faq.answer: Sustainable advantages include network effects, high switching costs, economies of scale, brand equity, proprietary technology, and regulatory protection. Test sustainability by asking: Can competitors copy this in under two years? Does it matter to customers? Do we execute it better than anyone else?

faq.question: Does this skill provide real competitor data?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides frameworks and templates for analysis. You need to gather competitor information from public sources, research, and customer feedback. The skill structures your analysis but does not retrieve or validate competitive intelligence.

faq.question: How often should I update competitive analysis?
faq.answer: Update competitive analysis regularly based on your market dynamics. Weekly monitoring of competitor product changes and news is recommended for fast-moving markets. Monthly positioning reviews and quarterly deep-dive analyses are standard practice for most businesses.
